intro: Pedicularis achilleifolia var. altaica, commonly known as the high mountain lousewort, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, characterized by its parasitic or hemiparasitic nature, though this variety is only partially parasitic. The plant typically grows in alpine and subalpine habitats, thriving in cool, moist environments with well-drained soils. It features showy, spurred flowers that are often pink or purple, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its morphology includes slender stems and opposite leaves, with the flowers arranged in a spike-like inflorescence.
